channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: How is Brazil’s President Lula doing on climate? Experts rate his performance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02511-x

Deforestation has dropped, but researchers who spoke to Nature say that he needs to take a stronger stance on fossil fuels.
item.dc:title: How is Brazil’s President Lula doing on climate? Experts rate his performance
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: R-loop dependent promoter-proximal termination ensures genome stability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06515-5

R-loop dependent promoter-proximal termination ensures genome stability
item.dc:title: R-loop dependent promoter-proximal termination ensures genome stability

item.title: Dopamine and glutamate regulate striatal acetylcholine in decision-making
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06492-9

Dopamine and glutamate regulate striatal acetylcholine in decision-making

item.title: Tautomeric Mixture Coordination Enables Efficient Lead-Free Perovskite LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06514-6

Tautomeric Mixture Coordination Enables Efficient Lead-Free Perovskite LEDs
item.dc:title: Tautomeric Mixture Coordination Enables Efficient Lead-Free Perovskite LEDs

item.title: China sees renewed surge in natural sciences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02158-8

After a dip during the pandemic, the country has boosted and broadened its high-quality research output.
item.dc:title: China sees renewed surge in natural sciences
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: These shapes roll in peculiar ways thanks to new mathematics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02538-0

An algorithm can design a shape to follow almost any repeating path downhill.
item.dc:title: These shapes roll in peculiar ways thanks to new mathematics
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Mapping China’s shifting research collaboration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02161-z

Changing patterns are emerging among the country’s international partnerships.
item.dc:title: Mapping China’s shifting research collaboration

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02164-w

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: How welcome are refugees in Europe? A giant study has some answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02537-1

A survey of 33,000 Europeans suggests overall support towards refugees has slightly increased, and how to get shapes to roll down wiggly paths using mathematics.
item.dc:title: How welcome are refugees in Europe? A giant study has some answers
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Neuronal migration prevents spatial competition in retinal morphogenesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06392-y

Experiments in zebrafish and human tissues show that, during retinal morphogenesis, emerging photoreceptor cells migrate in a bidirectional manner, which lessens competition for space and helps to ensure that the retina is formed correctly.
item.dc:title: Neuronal migration prevents spatial competition in retinal morphogenesis
item.dc:creator: Mauricio Rocha-Martins
Elisa Nerli
Jenny Kretzschmar
Martin Weigert
Jaroslav Icha
Eugene W. Myers
Caren Norden

item.title: No evidence for magnetic field effects on the behaviour of Drosophila
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06397-7

Following testing of magnetic field effects on 97,658 flies moving in a two-arm maze and on 10,960 flies performing spontaneous escape behaviour (negative geotaxis), no evidence was found for magnetically sensitive behaviour in Drosophila.
item.dc:title: No evidence for magnetic field effects on the behaviour of Drosophila
item.dc:creator: Marco Bassetto
Thomas Reichl
Dmitry Kobylkov
Daniel R. Kattnig
Michael Winklhofer
P. J. Hore
Henrik Mouritsen

item.title: Sustained wet–dry cycling on early Mars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06220-3

Observations by the Curiosity rover at Gale Crater on Mars indicate that high-frequency wet–dry cycling occurred on the early Martian surface, indicating a possible seasonal climate conducive to prebiotic evolution on early Mars.
item.dc:title: Sustained wet–dry cycling on early Mars
item.dc:creator: W. Rapin
G. Dromart
B. C. Clark
J. Schieber
E. S. Kite
L. C. Kah
L. M. Thompson
O. Gasnault
J. Lasue
P.-Y. Meslin
P. J. Gasda
N. L. Lanza

item.title: Reversed Holocene temperature–moisture relationship in the Horn of Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06272-5

Climate-proxy data indicate that during the last glacial period in the Horn of Africa higher temperatures were associated with greater moisture availability, whereas during the current interglacial period, as well as historically, higher temperatures have been associated with increased drought.
item.dc:title: Reversed Holocene temperature–moisture relationship in the Horn of Africa
item.dc:creator: A. J. Baxter
D. Verschuren
F. Peterse
D. G. Miralles
C. M. Martin-Jones
A. Maitituerdi
T. Van der Meeren

C. S. Lane
G. H. Haug
D. O. Olago
J. S. Sinninghe Damsté

item.title: Lactate limits CNS autoimmunity by stabilizing HIF-1α in dendritic cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06409-6

Lactate produced by dendritic cells (DCs) suppresses T-cell-mediated autoimmunity through a mechanism in which lactate activates HIF-1α–NDUFA4L2 signalling in DCs and thereby limits DC-mediated pro-inflammatory responses such as the development of encephalitogenic T cells.
item.dc:title: Lactate limits CNS autoimmunity by stabilizing HIF-1α in dendritic cells
item.dc:creator: Liliana M. Sanmarco

item.title: Carbonate-rich crust subduction drives the deep carbon and chlorine cycles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06211-4

New experiments show that most carbonates in carbonate-rich crustal rocks survive devolatilization and hydrous melting in cold and warm subduction zones, demonstrating their role in driving the deep carbon and chlorine cycles since the Mesoproterozoic.
item.dc:title: Carbonate-rich crust subduction drives the deep carbon and chlorine cycles
item.dc:creator: Chunfei Chen
Michael W. Förster
Stephen F. Foley
Svyatoslav S. Shcheka

item.title: Mitochondrial integrated stress response controls lung epithelial cell fate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06423-8

This study highlights the role of mitochondrial complex I-dependent NAD+ regeneration in directing lung epithelial cell fate during postnatal alveolar development by preventing pathological integrated stress response induction.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial integrated stress response controls lung epithelial cell fate
item.dc:creator: SeungHye Han

item.title: The recovery of European freshwater biodiversity has come to a halt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06400-1

Improvements in European freshwater biodiversity occurred mainly before 2010 but have since plateaued, and communities downstream of dams, urban areas and cropland were less likely to experience recovery.
item.dc:title: The recovery of European freshwater biodiversity has come to a halt

item.title: Solid-body trajectoids shaped to roll along desired pathways
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06306-y

An algorithm is developed to design a shape, a trajectoid, that can trace any given infinite periodic trajectory when rolling down a slope, finding unexpected implications for quantum and classical optics.
item.dc:title: Solid-body trajectoids shaped to roll along desired pathways
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav I. Sobolev
Ruoyu Dong
Tsvi Tlusty
Jean-Pierre Eckmann
Steve Granick
Bartosz A. Grzybowski

item.title: Europeans’ support for refugees of varying background is stable over time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06417-6

Surveys conducted in 15 European countries in 2016 and 2022 show stable attitudes towards asylum seekers and refugees with different attributes over this period with a slight increase in support for asylum seekers in general.
item.dc:title: Europeans’ support for refugees of varying background is stable over time
item.dc:creator: Kirk Bansak
Jens Hainmueller
Dominik Hangartner

item.title: Pines’ demon observed as a 3D acoustic plasmon in Sr<sub>2</sub>RuO<sub>4</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06318-8

Evidence is presented for a Pines’ demon as a three-dimensional acoustic plasmon in the multiband metal Sr2RuO4 from momentum-resolved electron energy-loss spectroscopy using a collimated, defocused beam with high momentum resolution.
item.dc:title: Pines’ demon observed as a 3D acoustic plasmon in Sr<sub>2</sub>RuO<sub>4</sub>
item.dc:creator: Ali A. Husain
Edwin W. Huang
Matteo Mitrano
Melinda S. Rak

Xuefei Guo
Hongbin Yang
Chanchal Sow
Yoshiteru Maeno
Bruno Uchoa
Tai C. Chiang
Philip E. Batson
Philip W. Phillips
Peter Abbamonte

item.title: Coral reefs benefit from reduced land–sea impacts under ocean warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06394-w

Surveys of reef change are combined with a unique 20-year time series of land–sea human impacts and the results show that integrated land–sea management could help achieve coastal ocean conservation goals and provide coral reefs with the best opportunity to persist in our changing climate.
item.dc:title: Coral reefs benefit from reduced land–sea impacts under ocean warming
item.dc:creator: Jamison M. Gove
Gareth J. Williams

item.title: TRIM5α restricts poxviruses and is antagonized by CypA and the viral protein C6
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06401-0

The well-characterized HIV restriction factor TRIM5α also restricts orthopoxviruses and is countered by the viral protein C6 and the proviral activity of CypA, which in turn is antagonized by CsA and derivatives alisporivir and NIM811.
item.dc:title: TRIM5α restricts poxviruses and is antagonized by CypA and the viral protein C6
item.dc:creator: Yiqi Zhao
Yongxu Lu
Samuel Richardson
Meghna Sreekumar
Jonas D. Albarnaz
Geoffrey L. Smith

item.title: Intrinsic dopamine and acetylcholine dynamics in the striatum of mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05995-9

In the absence of reward, dopamine and acetylcholine levels in the striatum fluctuate in a phasic manner, with their dynamics autonomously organized by extra-striatal neurons.
item.dc:title: Intrinsic dopamine and acetylcholine dynamics in the striatum of mice
item.dc:creator: Anne C. Krok
Marta Maltese
Pratik Mistry
Xiaolei Miao
Yulong Li
Nicolas X. Tritsch

item.title: Dissecting human population variation in single-cell responses to SARS-CoV-2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06422-9

Population differences in immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 can be explained by environmental exposures, but also by local adaptation acting through genetic variants acquired after admixture with archaic hominin forms.
item.dc:title: Dissecting human population variation in single-cell responses to SARS-CoV-2
item.dc:creator: Yann Aquino

item.title: A cool runaway greenhouse without surface magma ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06258-3

It is reported using a consistent climate model that pure steam atmospheres are commonly shaped by radiative layers, making their thermal structure strongly dependent on the stellar spectrum and internal heat flow.
item.dc:title: A cool runaway greenhouse without surface magma ocean
item.dc:creator: Franck Selsis
Jérémy Leconte
Martin Turbet
Guillaume Chaverot
Émeline Bolmont

item.title: Tail engagement of arrestin at the glucagon receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06420-x

Structures of the glucagon receptor bound to β-arrestin 1 are reported, providing further information about the arrestin-mediated modulation of G protein-coupled receptors.
item.dc:title: Tail engagement of arrestin at the glucagon receptor
item.dc:creator: Kun Chen
Chenhui Zhang
Shuling Lin
Xinyu Yan
Heng Cai

Limin Ma
Xiaojing Chu

Ya Zhu
Shuo Han
Qiang Zhao
Beili Wu

item.title: Diverse values of nature for sustainability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06406-9

Following a wide-ranging review of studies, reports and policies about nature’s multiple values, combinations of values-centred approaches are proposed to improve valuation of nature, address barriers to uptake in decision-making, and make transformative changes towards more just and sustainable futures.
item.dc:title: Diverse values of nature for sustainability

item.title: Chinese students stay local as favour falls with study abroad
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02162-y

Fewer opt to move overseas for study owing to factors such as the pandemic and geopolitical tensions.
item.dc:title: Chinese students stay local as favour falls with study abroad
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: How a controversial US drug policy could be harming cancer patients worldwide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02492-x

The FDA’s accelerated-approval process was designed to help people access life-saving drugs. But gaps in communication could mean that people are undergoing treatments known to be ineffective.
item.dc:title: How a controversial US drug policy could be harming cancer patients worldwide
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan

item.title: Threatened coastal species absent from Chinese protection lists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02513-9

The lack of legal protections for large coastal animals is leaving them — and their ecosystems — at risk, researchers say
item.dc:title: Threatened coastal species absent from Chinese protection lists
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: How China is capturing attention with landmark research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02160-0

From ancient sea species to clues on comets, papers by the country’s talented scientists are regularly making headlines.
item.dc:title: How China is capturing attention with landmark research
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy
Pratik Pawar
Sian Powell

item.title: GDP at 70: why genuinely sustainable development means settling a debate at the heart of economics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02509-5

Researchers advocating reform of the world’s main measure of growth have an opportunity to participate in the process that sets the rules.
item.dc:title: GDP at 70: why genuinely sustainable development means settling a debate at the heart of economics

item.title: Past climate unravels the eastern African paradox
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02297-y

Analyses of sediment from a lake in eastern Africa reveal the relationship between temperature and moisture over the past 75,000 years, and hint at why climate-model projections in the Horn of Africa are at odds with modern trends.
item.dc:title: Past climate unravels the eastern African paradox
item.dc:creator: Rachel L. Lupien

item.title: A coupled land–sea approach to coral-reef conservation in a warming ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02280-7

Local human-derived stressors combine with global ocean warming to threaten coral-reef persistence. Simultaneous reduction of human-derived stressors that originate on land, such as coastal run-off, and sea-based stressors, such as fishing pressure, resulted in greater coral-reef persistence before, during and after severe heat stress than did reduction of either alone.
item.dc:title: A coupled land–sea approach to coral-reef conservation in a warming ocean

item.title: European river recovery might have run out of steam
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02488-7

How has river quality in Europe changed over time? A detailed analysis of invertebrate data provides a picture of biological recovery from past problems, but also points to remaining challenges.
item.dc:title: European river recovery might have run out of steam
item.dc:creator: Ian P. Vaughan

item.title: Will China stay centre-stage for international research collaboration?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02163-x

As global research emerges from the fog of the pandemic, new influential networks are being formed.
item.dc:title: Will China stay centre-stage for international research collaboration?
item.dc:creator: Xin Xu

item.title: Avast, here cometh Actual Physics Man!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02465-0

A force equation for good.
item.dc:title: Avast, here cometh Actual Physics Man!
item.dc:creator: Filip Wiltgren

item.title: This moss survived 165 million years — and now it's under threat from climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02514-8

Ancient plant survived the formation of the Himalayas, but might now be facing extinction.
item.dc:title: This moss survived 165 million years — and now it's under threat from climate change
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Shaped to roll along a programmed periodic path
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02335-9

An algorithm has been developed for constructing a 3D shape that follows an infinitely repeating path as it rolls under gravity. The approach could have applications in quantum computing and medical imaging.
item.dc:title: Shaped to roll along a programmed periodic path
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Matsumoto
Henry Segerman

item.title: Insights into different populations’ immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02378-y

Analysis of immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 at single-cell resolution reveals marked differences across human populations that are caused by previous infections and genetic variation. Natural selection and past reproduction with Neanderthals contributed to these differing immune responses and disparities in COVID-19 risk.
item.dc:title: Insights into different populations’ immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection

item.title: Controlling pollution and overfishing can help protect coral reefs — but it’s not enough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02512-w

Local management of run-off and fishing intensity bolsters reef health but is no match for climate-induced heatwaves.
item.dc:title: Controlling pollution and overfishing can help protect coral reefs — but it’s not enough
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: What China’s leading position in natural sciences means for global research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02159-7

Its rise to the top has been long forecast, but what next for Chinese science in the post-pandemic era?
item.dc:title: What China’s leading position in natural sciences means for global research
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: Replication study casts doubt on magnetic sensing in flies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02489-6

It has long been thought that the fly Drosophila melanogaster can detect Earth’s magnetic field and offers an ideal system in which to examine this enigmatic sense. However, a rigorous replication of key studies fails to support this idea.
item.dc:title: Replication study casts doubt on magnetic sensing in flies
item.dc:creator: Eric J. Warrant

item.title: Assessing the values of nature to promote a sustainable future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02487-8

Understanding the diverse ways in which the natural world provides value aids informed policy decisions. The generation of a detailed catalogue of this diversity, and ways to assess values, paves the way to a more sustainable future.
item.dc:title: Assessing the values of nature to promote a sustainable future
item.dc:creator: Giulia Sajeva

Research challenges the myth that clean energy acts as a brake on global economic development.
item.dc:title: Clean energy can fuel the future — and make the world healthier

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02499-4

Bioprocess engineer Jesús E. Rodríguez’s team dreams of replacing all synthetic plastics with biodegradable products.
item.dc:title: Feeding bacteria seaweed to make compostable plastic
item.dc:creator: Patricia Maia Noronha

item.title: Is it time for tenure to evolve?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02498-5

After a spate of high-profile tenure denials, US academics are rethinking how this beleaguered academic process can be made more fair.
item.dc:title: Is it time for tenure to evolve?
item.dc:creator: Amber Dance

item.title: Daily briefing: Why insects don’t remember their early life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02522-8

How metamorphosis completely rewires fruit flies’ brains. Plus, research links air pollution to drug-resistant pathogens — but the mechanism remains unclear.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why insects don’t remember their early life
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Artificial-intelligence search engines wrangle academic literature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01907-z

Developers want to free scientists to focus on discovery and innovation by helping them to draw connections from a massive body of literature.
item.dc:title: Artificial-intelligence search engines wrangle academic literature
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Daily briefing: 23andMe DNA reveals living descendants of enslaved people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02520-w

DNA analysis from a genetic database finds nearly 42,000 living descendants of 27 African American furnace workers from the 18th and 19th century. Plus, efforts to replicate claims of a room-temperature superconductor fall short, and how to get the most out of remote conferences.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: 23andMe DNA reveals living descendants of enslaved people
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The bitter-sweet history of sugar, and the marvels of measurement: Books in Brief
item.content:encoded:

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The bitter-sweet history of sugar, and the marvels of measurement: Books in Brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: A single antibody tackles two childhood viruses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02428-5

Two pathogens that cause potentially serious respiratory infections in children are suppressed by a single protein.
item.dc:title: A single antibody tackles two childhood viruses

item.title: Claimed superconductor LK-99 is an online sensation — but replication efforts fall short
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02481-0

Social media is abuzz with chatter about the material, but some scientists are pushing back on the hype.
item.dc:title: Claimed superconductor LK-99 is an online sensation — but replication efforts fall short

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02507-7

item.dc:title: How remote conferencing broadened my horizons and opened career paths
item.dc:creator: Svetlana Ugarcina Perovic

item.title: Daily briefing: What the Henrietta Lacks settlement means for ethical research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02515-7

Researchers and legal specialists explain what the historic Henrietta Lacks settlement could mean for the scientific community. Plus, JWST finds a treasure trove of black holes and why sexism in science isn't resolved yet.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What the Henrietta Lacks settlement means for ethical research
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Indigenous youth must be at the forefront of climate diplomacy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02480-1

Holistic approaches to water and land management practised by Indigenous communities worldwide hold the key to a more sustainable future, say co-organizers of the Global Indigenous Youth Summit on Climate Change.
item.dc:title: Indigenous youth must be at the forefront of climate diplomacy

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02494-9

Molecular biologist whose work on isolated genes helped launch the era of recombinant DNA and gene editing.

item.title: JWST spots what could be a quasar from the early Universe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02429-4

The object’s deep red colour suggests it existed when the Universe was less than 700 million years old.
item.dc:title: JWST spots what could be a quasar from the early Universe

item.title: Cutting ships’ pollution has climate downside
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02430-x

Rules on the fuel burnt by ships at sea implemented in 2020 lead to local changes in cloud chemistry.
item.dc:title: Cutting ships’ pollution has climate downside

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals the living descendants of enslaved people through 23andMe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02478-9

A landmark genomic study raises the possibility that many more people could find links to distant ancestors through genetic analysis.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals the living descendants of enslaved people through 23andMe

item.title: Dr Semmelweis review: Mark Rylance play shows how hand washing saved hundreds of lives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02493-w

Professional pride and personal tragedy stymied ideas about how infections spread in the nineteenth century, suggests a show about maverick Hungarian doctor Ignaz Semmelweis.
item.dc:title: Dr Semmelweis review: Mark Rylance play shows how hand washing saved hundreds of lives

item.title: Daily briefing: Giant ancient whale could be heavier than blue whale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02500-0

Perucetus colossus, an ancient whale that lived 38 million years ago, is a new contender for the heaviest animal ever. Plus, four key questions on the new wave of anti-obesity drugs.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Giant ancient whale could be heavier than blue whale

item.dc:title: ‘It’s a dream’: JWST spies more black holes than astronomers predicted

item.content:encoded:
